About 200 fishermen who were captured by Pakistani authorities while fishing in the Arabian sea have returned to their homes in Gujarat after spending more than a year in Pakistan's jail. These fishermen were released from jail as a goodwill gesture by the Pakistani government amid the coronavirus pandemic.
The fishermen were sent to Pakistan's jails for violating the country's territorial waters. India and Pakistan have been involved in several conflicts over the years regarding the water-sharing of the rivers flowing from India to Pakistan. The fishermen, often belonging to the lower castes and marginalized sections of Indian society, have been caught in the middle of this conflict, facing imprisonment and violence.
However, experts believe that the release of these fishermen might lead to a renewed dialogue between the two countries on the issue of water-sharing, as the fishing communities on both sides of the border have been demanding a resolution to this issue for a long time.
Moreover, the release of these fishermen is also a positive step towards improving the people-to-people ties between India and Pakistan, which have been strained for decades due to various political and military conflicts.
The release of the 200 fishermen from Pakistan jail is a welcome move, and it provides a ray of hope for the thousands of other fishermen who are still languishing in the jails of both countries. It is time for India and Pakistan to work towards a peaceful resolution of their water-sharing disputes and protect the rights of the fishing communities.

After spending years in a Pakistan jail, 200 Indian fishermen have finally returned home to Gujarat. It all started when these fishermen, along with many others, were caught by Pakistani authorities for entering their waters illegally. They were charged with violations of maritime laws and thrown into jail without any communication with their families or the Indian government. Their future looked bleak until a ray of hope shone through an unexpected source.
A group of Pakistani human rights activists took up the case of these Indian fishermen and started a campaign to get them released. They argued that these fishermen were not criminals but poor fishermen who had strayed into Pakistani waters while fishing. They also highlighted the fact that many Pakistani fishermen were also languishing in Indian jails under similar circumstances. Their campaign caught the attention of the media and the public, and eventually, the Pakistani authorities were forced to reconsider their case.
After years of waiting and hoping, these 200 fishermen finally got their freedom and returned to their families in Gujarat. Their emotional reunion with their loved ones was a sight to behold, and it reminded us all that hope and unity can triumph over adversity and hatred.
The plight of Indian and Pakistani fishermen caught in each other's waters is a long-standing issue that has affected the lives of several families. In many cases, these fishermen are poor and illiterate, and they have no idea about the maritime laws of the neighboring countries. They get caught unintentionally while fishing and are then subjected to years of imprisonment and hardship.

The release of 200 Indian fishermen from a Pakistani jail has brought cheers to their families and the fishing community in Gujarat's Vadodara. Let's take a closer look at their case, and the larger issues it reflects.
For over a year, 200 Indian fishermen were jailed in Pakistan for fishing in the country's territorial waters. Many of them were arrested because of a lack of technology to determine their exact location in the sea. Despite various efforts by the Indian government and NGOs, their release was delayed due to bureaucratic hurdles and political tensions between the two countries. Finally, after 13 months, they were released and brought back to India.
The fishermen were welcomed with open arms by their families and the local fishing community. They talked about the hardships they had to face in the Pakistani jail and how they missed their loved ones. Despite their ordeal, they were happy to be back home and eager to get back to their profession.
The fishermen's case highlights the lack of technology and equipment in the fishing industry, which makes it difficult for fishermen to determine their exact location in the sea. This often leads to them accidentally crossing international waters and getting arrested by neighboring countries. The Indian government needs to invest in modern technology and educate fishermen about the dangers of fishing in prohibited waters.
The case also reflects the ongoing diplomatic tensions between India and Pakistan, which have often resulted in the arrest and detention of fishermen from both countries. While the release of these fishermen is a positive step towards improving relations between the two countries, there is a need for a permanent solution to the issue of fishermen getting arrested and jailed due to political tensions.

India and Pakistan have a long-standing dispute over fishing rights in the Arabian Sea, which has frequently resulted in the arrest of fishermen from both countries. However, amidst the ongoing tensions, a positive development has taken place in the form of the release of 200 Indian fishermen from a Pakistani jail.
These 200 Indian fishermen were arrested by the Pakistani authorities for fishing in their waters without permission. They were jailed for several months, causing immense hardship to their families back home. After persistent efforts by the Indian government and various human rights organizations, the Pakistani authorities agreed to release them as a goodwill gesture.
This is not the first time that fishermen have been caught in the crossfire of the India-Pakistan conflict. In 2016, Pakistan released 219 Indian fishermen as a goodwill gesture on the occasion of Eid. Similarly, in 2015, India released 88 Pakistani fishermen who had been incarcerated for over a year. Both these incidents were hailed as positive developments by the leadership of both countries.
The most well-known case of fishermen being caught in troubled waters is that of the fishing boat Kuber, which was hijacked by terrorists belonging to the Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT) organization in November 2008. The terrorists used the boat to reach Mumbai and carry out the infamous 26/11 attacks, in which over 170 people lost their lives. The Kuber was owned by a fisherman from Gujarat, who had rented it out to a group of people who claimed to be fishermen from Tamil Nadu. The incident highlights the vulnerability of fishermen in the region and the urgent need for better coordination between the security agencies of India and Pakistan.
The release of the 200 Indian fishermen is a small but significant step towards normalizing relations between India and Pakistan. It is heartening to see that the human rights of these fishermen were given due consideration by the Pakistani authorities. It is hoped that similar gestures will be made by both countries in the future, leading to a more peaceful and prosperous South Asia.

On 26th October 2020, India and the United States signed a landmark defence pact, the Basic Exchange and Cooperation Agreement (BECA) during the Ministerial Two-Plus-Two Dialogue held in New Delhi. The accord paves the way for the two countries to deepen their defence ties and effectively counter the aggressive actions of China in the Indo-Pacific region. This latest move is part of the ambitious roadmap that was laid out by the two countries in 2018, in which they agreed to strengthen their partnership in several key areas, including defence, trade, and energy.
China's rising power and influence pose a significant threat to the world's democratic countries. The Chinese Communist Party (CCP) has been pursuing an expansionist policy in the Indo-Pacific region, claiming sovereignty over a large part of the South China Sea and even creating new islands to assert its dominance. Beijing has also been using its economic clout to coerce other countries into obeying its demands, and its human rights abuses are well documented.
The Indian government has been increasingly concerned about China's activities along its borders as well as its growing involvement in Nepal, Sri Lanka, and other neighbouring countries. In June 2020, the Chinese army started an aggressive move by establishing itself along the Line of Actual Control (LAC) in the Galwan Valley, marking the first deadly clash between the two armies in more than 40 years. The incident has further deteriorated the relations between the two nations, with India adopting a more assertive stance to protect its sovereignty and territorial integrity.
The defence partnership between India and the United States has been steadily growing over the past decade. In 2005, the two countries signed a Defence Framework Agreement, which paved the way for joint military exercises, defence trade, and co-production of defence equipment. Since then, the two countries have signed several other agreements, including the Logistics Exchange Memorandum of Agreement (LEMOA) in 2016 and the Communications Compatibility and Security Agreement (COMCASA) in 2018.
The BECA, the latest addition to this list, is a geospatial intelligence-sharing pact. Under the agreement, the US will share advanced satellite and other real-time data with India to help improve its defence capabilities and enhance its situational awareness. This information will be useful for India in enhancing its surveillance capabilities of its borders with Pakistan and China.

On June 15th, 2020, the world watched in disbelief as the Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA) ambushed and brutally killed 20 Indian soldiers at Galwan Valley along the Line of Actual Control (LAC). The incident reiterated the fact that India was lagging behind China in terms of infrastructure capabilities along the LAC. But can India catch up to China in this race?
Despite the setback at Galwan Valley, India has been making progress in improving its infrastructure capabilities along the LAC. One such example is the construction of the Atal Tunnel, which was recently inaugurated by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The Atal Tunnel, located on the Rohtang Pass, is the longest highway tunnel in the world, and would provide all-weather access to Ladakh.
Another example is the construction of a strategic road in Arunachal Pradesh, which connects Tawang with the rest of the country. The road, which was completed in 2019, is expected to enhance India's defence capabilities in the region.
One of the key agencies responsible for infrastructure development along the LAC is the Border Roads Organisation (BRO). The BRO, which comes under the Ministry of Defence, is responsible for the construction and maintenance of roads and infrastructure in India's border areas.
BRO has been making steady progress towards improving India's infrastructure capabilities along the LAC. In the last few years, BRO has completed the construction of several strategic roads, bridges and tunnels in the region. For instance, the BRO recently completed the construction of a 19-km-long all-weather road in Sikkim, which connects the army bases at Nathu La and Sherathang with Gangtok.

China recently accused India of intentionally blocking the visa applications of journalists from China's state-owned media organization, Xinhua News Agency. The accusation came after Indian authorities reportedly stalled the visa applications of at least five journalists working for Xinhua News Agency, setting off a diplomatic tussle between the two nations.
The journalists in question had applied for visa extensions, which are typically renewed a few weeks before their expiration. However, the applications were put on hold by the Indian authorities, who cited "technical issues." China accused India of deliberately delaying the visas to intimidate the journalists and limit their access to information.
Indian officials, on the other hand, claimed that the delay was due to a backlog of visa applications, which they have been trying to clear up. They asserted that the visa applications of the Xinhua journalists were being reviewed, and there was no intentional delay or prejudice against them.
The current spat between China and India over the Xinhua journalists' visa applications is not the first instance of a tussle between the two nations over media access. In 2019, China denied a visa to an Indian journalist who worked for The Hindu. This was believed to be a retaliation against India for denying visas to a few Chinese journalists the previous year.
The spat between China and India has also spilled over into the digital space. In 2020, India banned over 200 Chinese mobile apps, including the popular social media platform TikTok, citing national security concerns. In retaliation, China banned several Indian mobile apps and websites, including the news aggregator app Inshorts and the e-commerce platform Shein.

The ongoing trade war between China and the United States has escalated into a geopolitical battle that has far-reaching effects. In a latest move that intensifies the tension, China has rejected a high level military dialogue with the US. The Chinese government cited the recent arms sales to Taiwan and the South China Sea as the reasons behind the move. This has led to concerns about possible military confrontations or even war between the two superpowers.
The South China Sea is a disputed territory between China and several other countries including Vietnam, the Philippines, Malaysia and Brunei. China claims sovereignty over almost all of the islands, reefs and waters in the area, which has a strategic and economic importance with rich resources such as oil, gas and fish. The US has been involved in the dispute by conducting freedom of navigation operations, which China considers as a violation of its territorial sovereignty. The US has also been providing military assistance to some of the countries in the region, which China sees as undermining its influence.
The trade war between China and the US began in 2018 when the US imposed tariffs on Chinese goods in an attempt to reduce the trade deficit and protect domestic industries. China responded with retaliatory tariffs on US goods. The dispute has escalated with both countries imposing tariffs on billions of dollars' worth of goods. The US has also accused China of intellectual property theft and unfair trade practices. The trade war has not only affected the economy of both countries but also the global economy.
The US recently approved a $2.2 billion arms sale to Taiwan, which China considers as a violation of its One-China policy. China has warned that it will take necessary measures to safeguard its sovereignty and security. The sale includes tanks, missiles and other military equipment that can be used against China. Taiwan has been a disputed territory between China and the US since the Chinese civil war in 1949.

China is a country of great diversity, with a vast landscape and a varied population. However, this diversity is also a challenge, as geographic divides complicate the demographics of the country. The aging population, the lopsided gender ratio, and the rural-urban divide are all challenges that China must face as it moves forward.
China is currently the world's most populous country, with a population of over 1.4 billion people. However, this population is rapidly aging. China's one-child policy, which was in effect from 1979 to 2015, has had a profound impact on the demographics of the country. The policy was put in place to curb population growth, but it also had the unintended consequence of creating a demographic time bomb. Today, China has a rapidly aging population, with a median age of 41.4 years.
This aging population creates several challenges for China. Firstly, it puts a strain on the country's social welfare system. With a growing number of elderly citizens, China will need to provide more support in the form of healthcare, pensions, and social services. Secondly, it could lead to a decline in economic growth. An aging population means a shrinking workforce, which could result in a slowdown in the economy. Finally, it creates a potential demographic crisis, with fewer young people to support a growing elderly population.
China's one-child policy also had another unintended consequence: a highly lopsided gender ratio. The policy led to a strong preference for male children, as they were seen as having more economic potential. This preference led to many cases of female infanticide and selective abortion, resulting in a gender imbalance in the population.
Today, China has a population that is skewed towards males. The gender ratio at birth is around 115 males to 100 females, far above the natural ratio of 105 males to 100 females. This imbalance creates several challenges for China. Firstly, it creates a potential demographic crisis, with fewer women available for marriage and reproduction. Secondly, it could lead to social unrest, as the large number of unmarried men may become a destabilizing force in society. Finally, it could lead to an increase in human trafficking and other forms of exploitation.

China's rise as a global power has been a topic of much discussion in recent years. While some argue that its growing influence threatens the established world order, others see it as an opportunity for the developing world to have a greater say on the global stage. In this article, we explore how China's rise is giving a voice to the developing world.
One of the key ways that China is empowering the developing world is through its Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). This ambitious infrastructure development plan seeks to connect Asia, Europe, and Africa through a series of roads, railways, ports, and other infrastructure projects.
